content.description: This fingery problem starts on two low crimps and crosses to a finger jug. Big moves between small incut crimps lead to the final crux - a hard move to a sloping shelf from a small, flat crimp. This is a fun climb and a good first V7 for a strong crimper. It helps to be a little shorter.

Short and Sweet is a short boulder problem that may involve two heel hooks. The crux is standing up from your second heel hook. Grab a sloper or jug on the top right of the rock. Then stand up, and top out.
content.location: This climb starts on the rightmost side of Millenium Boulder next to the crimpy V4/5. Start in the crack/jug, and make your way to the right and up.

content.description:
This is a very poor problem - not worth climbing unless you've climbed The Hideaway out. 

  Start super low and do awkward moves to work your way up and left. Top out left of The Pocket Problem.

This is an awkward, but fun problem. 

  Start on good flat crimps and cross to a good sidepull. From here, hike your feet up and work upwards until you reach a hard rock over move. Once you're well established on the slab, it's pretty easy to the top.

Start as for The Pocket Problem, traverse a low, crimpy seam into the starting holds of Tips Ahoy (submitted as Tips Away), and then climb Tips Ahoy (submitted as Tips Away). This is VERY contrived, seeing as you could top out on problems of several climbs both harder and easier.
content.protection: 2-3 pads and somebody to move them if worried about the initial traverse.

content.description: Sit start on a big jug and pull up to small crimps. Continue up and right and top out (grab the tree if you want). The start is a bit awkward and the climb as a whole is no gem, but it is definitely worth doing and is a good warm up if you are working the harder climbs on the boulder.
content.location: This is the rightmost climb on the Millennium Boulder.

content.description:
This is a very awkward warm-up on the very left side of the boulder.

 Traverse left on jugs and then rock onto the left slab. The crux is pulling your leg from under the mini-roof.
Start on the very left side, on the starting holds of Eddy Money, traverse head-level holds all the way into...All the Way, and top out. It is quite contrived as well.
content.protection: 2 pads and a spotter to move them.

content.description: This is likely the best problem on the boulder. A huge move to a really cool, flat bar that doesn't quite face the way you need it to makes way to a crazy lock-off/mantle off of crimps. From here, follow good, slopey holds to an easy mantle.
Start as for "Tips Away/Ahoy", and move to the jug with your right hand. Jump to the jug on "all the way" (do not use the obvious intermediates). Top out as for "The Balance Bar".
content.location: The starting holds are the same as those of "Tips Away/Ahoy."

content.description: A fun dyno from two crimps to a jug (if you drop off here, it's considered V6) leads to an awkward topout involving sloping crimps and a high heel hook.
Millenium Boulder is a large boulder with a large variety of popular climbs. It starts overhung and then slabs out.
